head.title: Detecting Autism Early, When There's Hope

hedline.hl1: Detecting Autism Early, When There's Hope

block.p: Re ''Slow-Motion Miracle: One Boy's Journey Out of Autism's Grasp'' (Education page, Dec. 29):

James O'Neil and my son Gregg Pullano are autistically impaired children. They beat the odds against living their lives in the shadowy world of autism. I cry not for them, but for other autistic children who are not so lucky.
Re ''Slow-Motion Miracle: One Boy's Journey Out of Autism's Grasp'' (Education page, Dec. 29):

James O'Neil and my son Gregg Pullano are autistically impaired children. They beat the odds against living their lives in the shadowy world of autism. I cry not for them, but for other autistic children who are not so lucky.

Children show signs of autism at about 2 years of age. Diagnosis takes an average of four more years, missing the window of opportunity during which the autistic brain is capable of learning ''normal'' patterns, leading to an ability to function in society. All efforts should go into establishing a worldwide standard of medical care for detecting and diagnosing autism when symptoms first show, not four years later.
Annie Lewis East Lansing, Mich., Dec. 29, 2004
